components/esm/loadcell.hpp

00001 #ifndef _ESM_CELL_H
00002 #define _ESM_CELL_H
00003 
00004 #include "esm_reader.hpp"
00005 #include "defs.hpp"
00006 
00007 namespace ESM {
00008 
00009 /* Cell reference. This represents ONE object (of many) inside the
00010    cell. The cell references are not loaded as part of the normal
00011    loading process, but are rather loaded later on demand when we are
00012    setting up a specific cell.
00013  */
00014 class CellRef
00015 {
00016 public:
00017   int refnum;           // Reference number
00018   std::string refID;    // ID of object being referenced
00019 
00020   float scale;          // Scale applied to mesh
00021 
00022   // The NPC that owns this object (and will get angry if you steal
00023   // it)
00024   std::string owner;
00025 
00026   // I have no idea, looks like a link to a global variable?
00027   std::string glob;
00028 
00029   // ID of creature trapped in this soul gem (?)
00030   std::string soul;
00031 
00032   // ?? CNAM has a faction name, might be for objects/beds etc
00033   // belonging to a faction.
00034   std::string faction;
00035 
00036   // INDX might be PC faction rank required to use the item? Sometimes
00037   // is -1, which I assume means "any rank".
00038   int factIndex;
00039 
00040   // Depends on context - possibly weapon health, number of uses left
00041   // or weapon magic charge?
00042   float charge;
00043 
00044   // I have no idea, these are present some times, often along with
00045   // owner (ANAM) and sometimes otherwise. They are often (but not
00046   // always) 1. INTV is big for lights (possibly a float?), might have
00047   // something to do with remaining light "charge".
00048   int intv, nam9;
00049 
00050   // For doors - true if this door teleports to somewhere else, false
00051   // if it should open through animation.
00052   bool teleport;
00053 
00054   // Teleport location for the door, if this is a teleporting door.
00055   Position doorDest;
00056 
00057   // Destination cell for doors (optional)
00058   std::string destCell;
00059 
00060   // Lock level for doors and containers
00061   int lockLevel;
00062   std::string key, trap; // Key and trap ID names, if any
00063 
00064   // No idea - occurs ONCE in Morrowind.esm, for an activator
00065   char unam;
00066 
00067   // Occurs in Tribunal.esm, eg. in the cell "Mournhold, Plaza
00068   // Brindisi Dorom", where it has the value 100. Also only for
00069   // activators.
00070   int fltv;
00071 
00072   // Position and rotation of this object within the cell
00073   Position pos;
00074 };
00075 
00076 /* Cells hold data about objects, creatures, statics (rocks, walls,
00077    buildings) and landscape (for exterior cells). Cells frequently
00078    also has other associated LAND and PGRD records. Combined, all this
00079    data can be huge, and we cannot load it all at startup. Instead,
00080    the strategy we use is to remember the file position of each cell
00081    (using ESMReader::getContext()) and jumping back into place
00082    whenever we need to load a given cell.
00083  */
00084 struct Cell
00085 {
00086   enum Flags
00087     {
00088       Interior  = 0x01, // Interior cell
00089       HasWater  = 0x02, // Does this cell have a water surface
00090       NoSleep   = 0x04, // Is it allowed to sleep here (without a bed)
00091       QuasiEx   = 0x80  // Behave like exterior (Tribunal+), with
00092                         // skybox and weather
00093     };
00094 
00095   struct DATAstruct
00096   {
00097     int flags;
00098     int gridX, gridY;
00099   };
00100 
00101   struct AMBIstruct
00102   {
00103     Color ambient, sunlight, fog;
00104     float fogDensity;
00105   };
00106 
00107   // Interior cells are indexed by this (it's the 'id'), for exterior
00108   // cells it is optional.
00109   std::string name,
00110 
00111   // Optional region name for exterior and quasi-exterior cells.
00112     region;
00113 
00114   ESM_Context context; // File position
00115   DATAstruct data;
00116   AMBIstruct ambi;
00117   int water; // Water level
00118   int mapColor;
00119 
00120   void load(ESMReader &esm)
00121   {
00122     // Ignore this for now, it might mean we should delete the entire
00123     // cell?
00124     if(esm.isNextSub("DELE")) esm.skipHSub();
00125 
00126     esm.getHNT(data, "DATA", 12);
00127 
00128     // Water level
00129     water = 0;
00130 
00131     if(data.flags & Interior)
00132       {
00133         // Interior cells
00134 
00135         if(esm.isNextSub("INTV") || esm.isNextSub("WHGT"))
00136           esm.getHT(water);
00137 
00138         // Quasi-exterior cells have a region (which determines the
00139         // weather), pure interior cells have ambient lighting
00140         // instead.
00141         if(data.flags & QuasiEx)
00142           region = esm.getHNOString("RGNN");
00143         else
00144           esm.getHNT(ambi, "AMBI", 16);
00145       }
00146     else
00147       {
00148         // Exterior cells
00149         region = esm.getHNOString("RGNN");
00150         esm.getHNOT(mapColor, "NAM5");
00151       }
00152 
00153     // Save position of the cell references and move on
00154     context = esm.getContext();
00155     esm.skipRecord();
00156   }
00157 
00158   // Restore the given reader to the stored position. Will try to open
00159   // the file matching the stored file name. If you want to read from
00160   // somewhere other than the file system, you need to pre-open the
00161   // ESMReader, and the filename must match the stored filename
00162   // exactly.
00163   void restore(ESMReader &esm) const
00164   { esm.restoreContext(context); }
00165 
00166   /* Get the next reference in this cell, if any. Returns false when
00167      there are no more references in the cell.
00168 
00169      All fields of the CellRef struct are overwritten. You can safely
00170      reuse one memory location without blanking it between calls.
00171   */
00172   static bool getNextRef(ESMReader &esm, CellRef &ref)
00173   {
00174     if(!esm.hasMoreSubs()) return false;
00175 
00176     // Number of references in the cell? Maximum once in each cell,
00177     // but not always at the beginning, and not always right. In other
00178     // words, completely useless.
00179     {
00180       int i;
00181       esm.getHNOT(i, "NAM0");
00182     }
00183 
00184     esm.getHNT(ref.refnum, "FRMR");
00185     ref.refID = esm.getHNString("NAME");
00186 
00187     // getHNOT will not change the existing value if the subrecord is
00188     // missing
00189     ref.scale = 1.0;
00190     esm.getHNOT(ref.scale, "XSCL");
00191 
00192     ref.owner = esm.getHNOString("ANAM");
00193     ref.glob = esm.getHNOString("BNAM");
00194     ref.soul = esm.getHNOString("XSOL");
00195 
00196     ref.faction = esm.getHNOString("CNAM");
00197     ref.factIndex = -1;
00198     esm.getHNOT(ref.factIndex, "INDX");
00199 
00200     ref.charge = -1.0;
00201     esm.getHNOT(ref.charge, "XCHG");
00202 
00203     ref.intv = 0;
00204     ref.nam9 = 0;
00205     esm.getHNOT(ref.intv, "INTV");
00206     esm.getHNOT(ref.nam9, "NAM9");
00207 
00208     // Present for doors that teleport you to another cell.
00209     if(esm.isNextSub("DODT"))
00210       {
00211         ref.teleport = true;
00212         esm.getHT(ref.doorDest);
00213         ref.destCell = esm.getHNOString("DNAM");
00214       }
00215     else ref.teleport = false;
00216 
00217     // Integer, despite the name suggesting otherwise
00218     esm.getHNOT(ref.lockLevel, "FLTV");
00219     ref.key = esm.getHNOString("KNAM");
00220     ref.trap = esm.getHNOString("TNAM");
00221 
00222     ref.unam = 0;
00223     ref.fltv = 0;
00224     esm.getHNOT(ref.unam, "UNAM");
00225     esm.getHNOT(ref.fltv, "FLTV");
00226 
00227     esm.getHNT(ref.pos, "DATA", 24);
00228 
00229     return true;
00230   }
00231 };
00232 }
00233 #endif
